column1: Acute nicotine poisoning usually occurs in young children who accidentally chew on nicotine gum or patches.

Nicotine is found in: - Chewing tobacco - Cigarettes - Nicotine gum (Nicorette) - Nicotine patches (Habitrol, Nicoderm) - Pipe tobacco - Some insecticides - Tobacco leaves Note: This list may not be all-inclusive.

Symptoms of nicotine poisoning include: - Abdominal cramps - Agitation, restlessness, or excitement - Burning sensation in mouth - Coma - Confusion - Convulsions - Depression - Difficulty breathing - Drooling (increased salivation) - Fainting - Headache - Muscle twitching - Fast and pounding heartbeat followed by slow heart rate - Rapid breathing - Stopped breathing - Vomiting - Weakness

The person may receive: - Activated charcoal - Airway support, including oxygen, breathing tube through the mouth (intubation), and breathing machine (ventilator) - Blood and urine tests - Chest x-ray - EKG (electrocardiogram, or heart tracing) - Fluids through a vein (IV) - Laxative - Medicines to treat symptoms, including agitation, rapid heart rate, seizures, and nausea
